《中国近现代史纲要》是全国高等学校开设的公共思想政治理论课。本课程的任务，主要是帮助学生认识近现代中国社会发展和革命发展的历史进程及其内在规律，“了解国史、国情，深刻领会历史和人民怎样选择了马克思主义，怎样选择了中国共产党，怎样选择了社会主义道路”。本课程要求学生懂得近现代中国是一代又一代的仁人志士和人民群众为救亡图存和实现中华民族的伟大复兴而英勇奋斗、艰苦探索的历史；尤其是全国各族人民在中国共产党的领导下，经过新民主主义革命，赢得民族独立和人民解放的历史；经过社会主义革命、建设和改革，把一个极度贫弱的旧中国逐渐变成一个初步繁荣昌盛、充满生机和活力的社会主义新中国的历史。认清只有在中国共产党领导下，坚持社会主义道路，才能救中国和发展中国，培养有理想、有道德、有文化、守纪律的社会主义新人。
《马克思主义基本原理概论》是全校本科学生的政治理论必修课。本课程围绕什么是马克思主义，为什么要始终坚持马克思主义，如何坚持和发展马克思主义这个主题，以阐释马克思主义世界观、方法论为重点，以人类社会发展的基本规律为主线，全面阐明马克思主义的基本理论、基本立场、基本观点和基本方法，涵盖了马克思主义哲学、政治经济学和科学社会主义三个主要组成部分在内的全部重要内容。本课程重点学习马克思主义认识和观察物质世界、人类历史和社会生活关系的基本立场、观点和方法，学习、掌握辩证唯物主义和历史唯物主义的世界观和方法论，学习了解资本主义生产关系的实质及其发展趋势，学习了解社会主义、共产主义的客观必然性和建设发展的历史过程性。要求学生从整体上把握马克思主义基本原理，正确认识人类社会发展规律，具体包含正确认识物质世界的发展规律，资本主义社会的发展规律和社会主义社会的发展规律。理解马克思主义理论是无产阶级及其政党观察问题、变革现实的世界观和方法论，学会运用马克思主义的立场、观点与方法去分析和解决问题，为社会主义事业努力奋斗。

本课程主要以全球化为大背景，阐释了当今主要大国之间的历史、现状及其相互之间关系的发展趋势与轨迹。　经济和科技全球化、世界多极化等相对有利的国际大背景促进了大国协调与合作，全球范围内经济增长面临质的深化带动了国际分工以及资本、人才、资源的跨国流动，科技发展日新月异，世界能源与资源供应问题日益突出，经济全球化负面影响日益突出；世界多极化、国际关系民主化和发展模式多样化在曲折中前进，世界各国共同面对的挑战也同步增加促使传统大国、新兴大国之间相互合作的基础日益广泛而牢固，相互依存大大加深。同时对大国关系互动的不确定性和竞争性一面仍然需要高度关注，保持足够清醒。大国冲突消弭和退场的过程艰难而漫长。大国之间的对抗性减弱但并未消失，依然不同程度存在。地缘政治争夺、战略资源争夺以及冷战思维等诸多因素依然深刻制约着大国关系的良性发展。通过这门课程的学习，使学生对当今大国间的竞争合作关系保持清醒的认识，对中国在大国关系中所扮演的角色及政府的对外政策有一个正确的认识。z

医事法学是专门研究和探讨与医疗事务相关的法律体系、法律理论和法律制度的学科，面向本科学生（尤其是医科学生）开设。通过医事法学的学习，可以了解和掌握我国医事法律法规的基本体系，培养学生的职业法律思维能力，提高学生的职业法律意识。课程力图将知识的传授与实践能力的培养有机的结合起来，在坚持体系化讲授医事法学知识的同时，积极引入“以问题为导向”的学习方式和案例教学方法。医事法学是一门实践性很强的学科。以案例教学法（CBL）为基本手段，本课程将把当前医疗实践中产生的一些重大、疑难法律案例引入课堂，通过小组讨论、班级讨论等多种教学方式鼓励学生积极探讨解决途径，引导学生形成法律的思维方式，培养学生运用医事法解决执业实践问题的能力。

本课程在教学中会根据医事法律法规的修订情况及时补充相应内容，课程内容主要包括以下五大部分：
第一部分为医事法学的学科概述；
第二部分是医事法学的基本理论与基本原理，重点讲授对医疗实践具有重大影响的医事法律制度；
第三部分为医事法学相关纠纷的处理与解决，重点讲授医疗侵权纠纷的处理与解决；
第四部分为医疗技术发展产生的法律问题；
第五部分为医疗事务领域的法律责任问题，重点讲授医疗事务领域的行政法律责任与刑事法律责任。
此外，本课程在教学中会积极关注社会生活中医事方面的热点、焦点事件中出现的法律问题。通过将医事法学课程的学习与社会热点、难点医事法问题的挂钩，让学生们投人到现实的医事法问题情景中。通过鼓励学生自主探究，激发和支持他们的“批判思维”、“论证意识”和“辩论能力”，加深学生对每一部分相关内容的理解，切实提高他们运用医事法解决未来执业实践中可能面临的法律问题的能力。

The Russian Media in Terms of Modern Political Transformation
The Russian Media in Terms of Modern Political Transformation

Russia nowadays is being actively transformed in terms of new political reality. Its stance on the international arena is far from being stable. The current situation in this country initiates a very contradictory politics towards international community. The Russian media seem to be a good illustration of these contradictions given their organizational structure, political and economic subordination to the state hierarchy. Yet many insights observed the Russian media contents have been imprinted historically and developed long before modern transition. The main goal of the course is to introduce students to the basic orientations of Russian politics and the role of the media in its evolution. The lecturer intends to investigate the spiritual and political priorities in the system of modern Russian governance and their influence on the Russian media given the historic origins of this relationship. This background sheds light on current relationship between political institutions and the media in Russia following the coverage by the latter of the most pivotal political events. Following it, during the counrse current media trends are supposed to be investigated including the content of political information on Russian television as being a main source of mass information in Russian society. The role of journalists as the bearers of new political values is also to be envisaged. A dpecific attention is going to be paid to the issues of ethic, objectivity and journalistic professionalism in Russia.
The BRICS Constellation and Its Future: The View from The Russian Media
The BRICS Constellation and Its Future: The View from The Russian Media

The course investigates the political position of BRICS organization and its perspectives. More specifically, the Russian political position is being envisaged. For the last decade of the BRICS existence six high-level summits took place, and the organization has passed through the political and economic self-determination, and outlined the prospects of its geographical expansion. However, the mass audience in Russia still has very vague perceptions about the BRICS. This highlights the problem of national responsibility and the involvement of Russian media into these matters/ To what extent the Russian media take these issues seriously? How the BRICS issues can be covered by the media to make the situation more visualized by the public? These are the questions which are worth deeply investigating during the course. Thereby the author raises not only the issues of the political and economic cooperation between the BRICS countries as such but also the problems of the media involvement in the BRICS informational priorities. A special survey conducted for 2012-2016 years by the group of media experts from the BRICS countries including the author himself is under Strovskii’s grave investigation. The author sorts out the main ideas concerning political and economic stance of the BRICS countries which have become investigated by the above group of media experts. This makes the course itself as inter-disciplinary and useful for the students from different institutions of Sichuan university.

Purpose of Course: Modern society revolves around its cities, which are both stable and changing depending on where and how often you look. California is more dynamic than Wisconsin, say, but less so than the Peoples Republic of China. Yet how cities work is mainly understood through their various parts – streets, houses, etc. – and their functions – jobs, transportation, and so on. These conflicts, and the issues they concern, are pivotal. Some questions addressed are strictly positive; e.g., what is growth, what does infrastructure cost, how does urban development affect the quality of life? Others are normative; e.g., should development be fast or slow? There is much to learn about, first, how to think about how communities function and, second, what to do about it.
Public policies toward cities are mainly aimed at these pieces rather than at the whole, but an understanding of the whole (and its parts) makes for successful policies. This is a survey course of many such elements, aimed at helping you get your head around some big issues of the day, such as poverty and growth, by improving your familiarity with their details. Among other issues, we will look at 4 major, related themes:
? Economic development and Community Development (including poverty)
? Housing markets ? Public finances

Purpose of Course: Much modern evidence indicates that contemporary urban design and urban form are problematic for a host of reasons. Land consumption for urban development is particularly a concern when converted from potentially more valuable land uses, including land devoted to scenic, recreational, and habitat purposes. More city traffic jeopardizes our health, our sanity, and our pocketbook, as well as the environment. The poor are isolated in or relegated to high crime and low amenity communities that cannot finance basic services and from which they cannot afford to leave. Neighborhoods fail to function as they seemed to before, in part because the modern subdivision places social, physical and economic obstacles in their path. Perhaps most plainly, many cities and indeed many new urban areas especially are both unattractive and uninspiring. The solutions tend toward bold policy interventions. Cities should dramatically increase their densities, cars should be discouraged, open space should be removed from development, zoning codes should be burned, and so on. Among other issues, we will focus on 2 major, related themes:
? Urban form (and alternatives)
? Traffic problems (and urban design solutions)
